, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Right lower quadrant:--</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cecum<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Appendix<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ascending Colon<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Right ovary and\nFallopian tube<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Right ureter<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Clinical significance-- &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">If abdominal pain or\nsigns of peritonitis are localised in the LLQ, colitis, diverticulitis,\nureteral colic or pain due to ovarian cysts or pelvic inflammatory disease may\nbe suspected. Examples of tumors in the left lower quadrant include colon\ncancer and ovarian tumor.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The LUQ may be painful\nor tender in the case of intestinal malrotation. The RUQ may be painful or\ntender in hepatitis, cholecystitis, and peptic ulcer. The RLQ may be painful\nand/or tender in such conditions as appendicitis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ileocecal valve pain\nhas always been mistaken by inexperienced doctors as \u2018grumbling appendix\u2019.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ileocecal valve can show such acute\npainful stress that it can sometimes be confused with an inflamed appendix.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nvalve is controlled by three sources: the digestion process, the nervous\nsystem, and the hormone system.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A healthy Ileocecal valve\nwould stay closed to hold the food in the small intestines until the digestion\nand absorption of nutrients is completed and it gets the green signal to open\nup momentarily. It will then open up and let the digested food remains enter\ninto the large intestines.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If this green signal\nsystem OPEN SESAME does not work \u2013the valve could stay open for more time .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As\na result, the food to be digested would pass through the small intestines too\nfast, too few nutrients would be absorbed, and the mostly undigested food would\nenter the colon, where bacterial processes could cause a lot of gas; and you\nmight experience diarrhea.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Second, the ileocecal\nvalve could be shut most of the time. Food would the stay for too long in the\nsmall intestines, and could start to rot and cause gas in the small intestines;\ntoxins from the rotting food could be absorbed into you system and force the\nliver to work overtime; you could feel bloated, and experience constipation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If you take medication\nfor heartburn, especially proton pump inhibitors, your chances of having SIBO\nare high.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/11/proton-pump-inhibitors-and-its-bad.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/11/proton-pump-inhibitors-and-its-bad.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most of the time&nbsp; SIBO is the cause of the heart burn symptoms\nto begin with.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Gastric bypass surgery\nincreases risk for SIBO because it reduces not only acid production but how\nwell we digest and absorb our food.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Our intestinal tract\nsecretes an important antibody called IgA .. This is part of our immune system.\nIf we are stressed these antibodies are lowered, weakening our immune system\nand allowing for bacterial overgrowth.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Immunoglobulin A (IgA )\nis an antibody that plays a crucial role in the immune function of mucous (\nKAPHA ) membranes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The amount of IgA\nproduced in association with mucosal membranes is greater than all other types\nof antibody combined. In absolute terms, between three and five grams are\nsecreted into the intestinal lumen each day.&nbsp;\nThis represents up to 15% of total immunoglobulins produced throughout\nthe body<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The intestinal immune\nsystem represents the largest and most complex portion of the immune system,\nand employs a number of normal host defenses The gut\u2019s intestinal barrier is\ncomposed of a thick secreted mucus layer, an epithelial layer, and the\nunderlying nonepithelial mucosal cells, such as lymphocytes&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The protective\nmucus layer ( KAPHA ) provides both a physical and a chemical barrier to\nmicrobes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The epithelial layer\nacts as a structural barrier via tight junctions between cells.&nbsp; Epithelial cells also emit signals that\nregulate innate and adaptive immunity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Beneath the epithelium\nlies a connective tissue layer known as the lamina propria, which contains\nvarious immune cells such as T lymphocytes, macrophages, dendritic cells, and\nantibody-secreting IgA plasma cells.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The constant balance\nand interplay of physiologic and immunologic responses maintains the health and\nnormal function of the gut <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The major antibodies\nfound on mucous membranes are secretory IgA, which function primarily by binding\nmicroorganisms and thereby preventing their contact with the host tissues<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Secretory IgA is the\nprimary antibody in mucous membranes in humans, which are the entry point for\nmost foreign antigens (e.g., in the nose, lungs, and gut lining). It therefore\nplays a critical role in mucosal immunity\u2014the protection and homeostatic\nregulation of mucosal epithelia.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In\ndiscriminating between symbiotic, harmless (\u201ccommensal\u201d) bacteria and\npotentially life-threatening microorganisms, IgA helps the immune system to\ncontinuously monitor the gut contents, maintaining a balance between tolerance\nto the microbiota or other antigens encountered in a normal diet, and rapid\ndefense against microbial pathogens<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In early life, breast\nmilk-derived maternal IgA performs these functions until the intestinal immune\nsystem of the offspring can take over. IgA does allow some translocation of\nIgA-antigen complexes into the mucosa, controlling the dialog between immune\nsystem and symbionts to ensure tolerance to innocuous proteins. When\npathogens/toxins threaten to invade the gut barrier, IgA supports the immune\nsystem in eliminating them.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Disruption\nof the balance between microbiota, intestinal epithelial cells, and mucosal\nimmune system can lead to pathologies with altered IgA production: Elevated\nfecal IgA levels may indicate an upregulated immune response to an antigen in\nthe gut (e.g., bacteria, parasites, viruses, yeasts, or other allergenic\nproteins).&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mucous ( KAPHA ) destroys\nbacteria and viruses, traps particles such as dirt, prevents water loss,\nhumidifies passageways, lubricates the movement of materials, and protects\nsurfaces from damage.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The stomach lining is covered by a protective layer of\nmucus. Glands in the stomach produce mucus, hydrochloric acid and an inactive\nenzyme called pepsinogen. In the stomach cavity, the hydrochloric acid changes\nthe pepsinogen into an active digestive enzyme called pepsin. This enzyme\ndigests proteins. The mucus layer acts as a barrier which prevents the stomach\nlining from being attacked by pepsin and acid.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the mucus layer in\nthe stomach is thinned or removed, which may happen during an infection by a bacterium\ncalled Helicobacter pylori, pepsin and acid may be able to attack the stomach\nlining. The infection can cause inflammation (gastritis) and sores called\nulcers. Glands in the lining of the small intestine and the large intestine\nalso produce mucus.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is often some mucus in stool, but generally not\nenough to be noticed. Noticeable amounts may appear in intestinal problems such\nas the diarrhea-predominant form of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The mucus\nlooks like a thin, glistening jelly. In ulcerative colitis, the lining of the\nlarge intestine is inflamed and ulcers develop. Mucus and blood are often\nreleased into the stool in this disorder.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At birth, the neonate's\nmucosal immune system is relatively undeveloped, but the colonization of\nintestinal flora after VAGINAL BIRTH and BREAST FEEDING promotes its\ndevelopment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Microbes can prevent\ngrowth of harmful pathogens by altering pH, consuming nutrients required for\npathogen survival, and secreting toxins and antibodies that inhibit growth of\npathogens<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Immunoglobulin A (IgA)\nis an antibody critical to immune function in mucous membranes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">IgA antibodies are one\nof the most important antibodies, as they are the body\u2019s first line of defence\nagainst bacteria and viruses. IgA antibodies may produce to certain foods when\nthe lining of the gastrointestinal tract (the mucous membrane) becomes inflamed\nor damaged.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Individuals with ulcerative colitis or Crohn\u2019s disease, or even\nthose with suspected \u2018leaky gut\u2019 may benefit from IgA testing. Asthma,\nheadaches, eczema, fatigue and irritable bowels are common conditions\nassociated with IgA reactions.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/gnZEge78_78/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/gnZEge78_78?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The migrating motor\ncomplex (MMC) is a neurological system that sweeps stuff down our digestive\ntract.&nbsp; This makes sense in terms of\nmoving our food down the digestive tract.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/ZeUlh9Cou38/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/ZeUlh9Cou38?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, an important function of the MMC is to sweep down bacteria so\nthey cannot over populate the small bowel.&nbsp;\nMMC dysfunction causes stasis (constipation) and allows for reproducing\nbacteria to achieve higher than normal numbers resulting in SIBO.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7CawfZek8Vk/WO99BrWBrJI/AAAAAAABSdU/DM7DWUW2J3Aidtm82INsJOfHeVLS1-GYgCEw/s1600/B97814377156R06000500_f050-004-9781437715606.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"336\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-7CawfZek8Vk/WO99BrWBrJI/AAAAAAABSdU/DM7DWUW2J3Aidtm82INsJOfHeVLS1-GYgCEw/s640/B97814377156R06000500_f050-004-9781437715606.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">I DARE INDIAs BEST GUT SPECIALIST DOCTORS--and MEDICAL COLLEGE PROFESSORS&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-FbvcfZTRfS8/WO99gmJj3fI/AAAAAAABSdg/wtn2Pqa4Mc8OBjeQ2dS2fTLT4XzJprFjQCLcB/s1600/SecretorWyIAG.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em;
